summary: A studio interview where the host addresses Newt Gingrich through audio clips and engages him on the topic of healthcare reform and government intervention.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man, identified as Newt Gingrich, Former Speaker of the House, engaged in a phone conversation. He is dressed in a dark suit and tie, seated in a professional studio environment with a microphone in front of him. The background includes a blackboard and a screen displaying the logo "GBTV" with the tagline "The truth lives here." Gingrich is seen gesturing with his hands while speaking, indicating an animated discussion. The setting is consistent throughout the video, with Gingrich maintaining his position at the desk, occasionally adjusting his posture and hand gestures. The on-screen text provides context to his role and the nature of the conversation, emphasizing the formal and professional atmosphere of the broadcast.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker introducing a topic, indicating that he will play audio. The audio then transitions to a brief segment featuring a single male speaker stating, "I am for people, individuals, exactly like automobile insurance, individuals having health insurance, and being required to have health insurance." He continues, expressing his intention to vote for a voucher system that would provide a government subsidy on a sliding scale to ensure that every individual has health insurance. The initial male speaker then returns, stating that the previous audio was from 1993, before indicating that the next clip is from 2011.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man identified as Newt Gingrich, a former Speaker of the House, is seen participating in a phone interview within a professional studio setting. He is dressed in a dark suit and tie, seated at a desk equipped with a microphone and multiple computer monitors. Gingrich is actively engaged in the conversation, gesturing with his right hand while speaking into the microphone. The background features a large screen displaying the logo "GBTV" along with the tagline "The truth lives here," and a model of the Empire State Building, suggesting a connection to New York City. The atmosphere is formal and focused, with Gingrich appearing to be in a serious discussion. The text overlay at the bottom of the screen provides his name and title, reinforcing his identity and role in the broadcast. Throughout the video, Gingrich maintains a composed demeanor, emphasizing his points with hand gestures, and the studio environment remains consistent, highlighting the professional nature of the interview.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing responsibility in healthcare and proposes requirements such as health insurance or posting a bond, suggesting individual accountability. Another male speaker then asks if that is not individual mandate, to which the first male speaker replied it's a variation on it. There is a transition to a new subject introduced by a male speaker: Paul Ryan trying to fix Medicare.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a suit is seen sitting in a radio studio, speaking into a microphone. He is identified as Newt Gingrich, a former Speaker of the House, as indicated by the text overlay on the screen. The studio is equipped with multiple computer monitors and a large screen displaying the logo "GBTV" with the tagline "The truth lives here." The man appears to be engaged in a phone conversation, as suggested by the text "(on the phone)" displayed on the screen. Throughout the video, he is seen making hand gestures, such as touching his face and pointing, while speaking. The background features a model of a building, possibly the Empire State Building, adding to the professional atmosphere of the studio. The overall setting suggests a serious and focused discussion taking place in a news or talk show environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker stating, "I don't think right-wing social engineering...any more desirable than left-wing social engineering...imposing radical change from the right or the left is a very good way for a free society to operate." He continues, mentioning that improvements can be made to Medicare and arguing against imposing sudden change. A second male speaker chimes in, questioning something Paul Ryan suggested. The first speaker responds, considering it "too big a jump" and favoring a voluntary system rather than imposition, stating he is against both Obamacare and conservative-imposed radical changes. The second male speaker then acknowledges with an "Okay." Lastly, a brief, indistinguishable sound follows.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man, identified as Newt Gingrich, Former Speaker of the House, participating in a phone interview in a professional studio setting. He is dressed in a dark suit and tie, seated at a desk with a microphone in front of him, indicating he is speaking or about to speak. The background includes a large screen displaying the logo "GBTV" with the tagline "truth lives here," suggesting the name of the broadcasting network. The studio is equipped with multiple computer monitors, papers, and a model of a famous skyscraper, adding to the professional atmosphere. Throughout the video, Gingrich appears engaged in conversation, occasionally looking to his side, possibly addressing someone off-camera or reacting to the conversation. The on-screen text consistently identifies him and his role, reinforcing his identity and the context of the interview. The overall setting and Gingrich's demeanor convey a formal and serious tone, typical of a political or news-related discussion.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a male speaker who presents an inquiry regarding "long-term individual mandate stuff," indicating an interest in the government finding solutions. The man begins to answer the question, restating what was asked, which was, should Republicans impose a program if it's unpopular? He continues by stating that in a free society, officials shouldn't impose things people disagree with. He mentions the debate over Obamacare and proposes implementing Medicare reforms as an optional choice, allowing people the freedom to negotiate with their doctor or hospital, increasing the ability to manage costs, but without imposing it on everybody across the board. He then suggests a migration toward the changes.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with gray hair and glasses, dressed in a dark suit, is seen sitting in a radio studio. He is speaking into a microphone, with a computer monitor and a model of the Empire State Building visible in the background. The studio has a dark green wall with a large screen displaying the logo "GBTV" and the slogan "The truth lives here." The man appears to be engaged in a phone conversation, as indicated by the text overlay at the bottom of the screen, which reads "Newt Gingrich, Former Speaker of the House, on the phone." The atmosphere is professional, and the man seems focused on the conversation. The video captures the man in various moments of speaking, with slight changes in his facial expressions and head movements, indicating an ongoing dialogue.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a proposal regarding Social Security. He speaks in a measured tone, explaining his view that younger people should have the option of a personal Social Security savings account, mentioning that actuarial estimates suggest the majority would prefer this system if given a choice. He emphasizes that this would be a voluntary decision, empowering individuals rather than imposing a system upon them.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man, identified as Newt Gingrich, Former Speaker of the House, seated at a desk in a professional studio environment. He is dressed in a dark suit and tie, with glasses, and is engaged in a phone conversation, as indicated by the text overlay "on the phone." Gingrich is positioned in front of a microphone, suggesting he is either speaking or listening intently. The background includes a large screen displaying the logo "GBTV" with the tagline "The truth lives here," and a model of the Empire State Building, adding to the studio's thematic decor. The lower third of the screen consistently displays Gingrich's name and title, reinforcing his identity and role. Throughout the video, Gingrich's facial expressions and body language convey a sense of focus and engagement in the conversation. The studio setting, with its professional equipment and branding, creates an atmosphere of a serious and informative broadcast.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker in a thoughtful tone contemplating how to accelerate reform in the country. He suggests that "giving people the right to choose" is the key. Another male interjects, stating that he wants to "get to a few things".

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with gray hair and glasses, dressed in a dark suit and blue tie, is seated at a desk with a microphone in front of him, engaged in a phone conversation. The desk is cluttered with papers and documents, suggesting a busy work environment. The background features a dark curtain, adding a formal atmosphere to the setting. On-screen text identifies the man as "Newt Gingrich, Former Speaker of the House," indicating his political background and the context of the conversation. The logo "GBTV" is visible, suggesting the broadcast is part of a news or talk show. Throughout the video, the man appears focused and engaged in the discussion, with slight variations in his facial expressions and posture, reflecting the dynamic nature of the conversation. The overall scene conveys a professional and serious tone, typical of a political interview or discussion.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker who seems to be in a conversation, mentioning support for the Department of Education and caution towards changing "Fannie and Freddy." The speaker has a somewhat formal tone.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man identified as Newt Gingrich, a former Speaker of the House, is seen participating in a phone interview. He is dressed in a dark suit and tie, seated at a desk with a microphone in front of him. The background features a dark wall with a logo that reads "GBTV" and the slogan "the truth lives here." Gingrich is actively engaged in the conversation, gesturing with his hands and occasionally touching his face, indicating a thoughtful or emphatic response. The setting appears to be a professional studio environment, with papers and a computer monitor visible on the desk. The atmosphere is serious and focused, with Gingrich's expressions and body language conveying his involvement in the discussion. The video maintains a consistent visual style, with Gingrich's actions and the studio setting remaining largely unchanged throughout the sequence.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker seemingly equating global warming with sitting down with Nancy Pelosi, conveying a dismissive tone. He acknowledges the previous statement may have been foolish. The speaker then references past statements and a book titled "Contract with the Earth" as well as a debate with John Kerry, where he advocated for reducing carbon loading in the atmosphere, to which he received applause from the crowd. During this time, the speaker mentions having John Kerry in the debate defending the private sector, while the speaker advocated for government support. The male speaker, speaking in a serious tone, concludes by calling for a green conservatism and proposing a dialogue for finding effective solutions.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with gray hair and glasses, dressed in a dark suit and tie, is seen sitting in a radio studio. He is speaking into a microphone, with a blackboard and a model of the Empire State Building visible in the background. The studio is equipped with multiple computer monitors and a desk cluttered with papers. The text overlay on the screen identifies him as "Newt Gingrich, Former Speaker of the House," and indicates that he is "on the phone." The logo "GBTV" and the tagline "the truth lives here" are displayed on a screen behind him. Throughout the video, the man appears engaged in conversation, occasionally looking to his left, suggesting interaction with someone off-camera. The setting and his attire convey a professional atmosphere, typical of a news or talk show environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker expressing his views on tax credits and carbon sequestration, stating if you have the "right level of tax credit" it wouldn't be completely voluntary and predicts most utilities would build carbon sequestering power plants. The speaker has a conversational tone. Another male interrupts and argues against governmental control and payment through tax credits, favoring private sector involvement. The tone becomes more argumentative with overlapping speech. Interwoven with this discussion, sounds suggesting a rural setting are heard, with consistent, medium-volume creaking that could be the sounds of wind, equipment operating, or a door. The audio concludes with a third male stating "help me out", and comments on multi-year stance.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with gray hair and glasses, dressed in a dark suit and tie, is seen speaking into a microphone in a radio studio. He is identified as "Newt Gingrich, Former Speaker of the House," as indicated by the text on the screen. Gingrich appears to be engaged in a phone conversation, as suggested by the text "(on the phone)" displayed alongside his name. The studio is equipped with multiple computer monitors and a large microphone, emphasizing the professional setting. The background features a blackboard and a sign that reads "GBTV The truth lives here," reinforcing the branding of the broadcasting network. Throughout the video, Gingrich's expressions and gestures suggest he is actively participating in the conversation, occasionally touching his face and adjusting his posture. The overall atmosphere is one of focused discussion, with Gingrich appearing to be a central figure in the broadcast.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker, who states he taught environmental studies and believes in the environment. His tone is measured and calm. He acknowledges evidence on both sides of the climate change argument and argues that having a larger nuclear program could reduce carbon in the atmosphere. The clip then ends abruptly.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with gray hair and glasses, dressed in a dark suit and tie, is seen sitting at a desk in a studio environment, engaged in a phone conversation. He is holding a microphone close to his mouth, indicating he is speaking or about to speak. The background features a large screen displaying the logo "GBTV" with the tagline "The truth lives here." The man appears to be in a professional setting, possibly a news or talk show studio, as suggested by the presence of multiple computer monitors and a model of a famous building, likely the Empire State Building, on the desk. Throughout the video, the man's expressions and gestures change slightly, reflecting his engagement in the conversation. The text overlay at the bottom of the screen identifies him as "Newt Gingrich, Former Speaker of the House," and notes that he is "on the phone." The overall atmosphere is one of a serious and professional discussion, with the man actively participating in the conversation.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker who talks about a "prudent thing" and "nuclear is one of the options." He continues in a similar, declarative tone discussing developing a "green coal plant" for carbon sequestration and its potential use in oil fields, which he claims is already being done in West Texas. The speaker is then interrupted by another male speaker, who questions the first about the possibility of fundamental change. The second speaker mentions voting for a "prescription drug bill" because he couldn't move, but.

The consistent visual elements and Gingrich's active participation create a coherent narrative of a significant phone interview or conversation being conducted in a professional broadcast environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker in a conversational tone, referencing the building of nuclear power plants under a "Gingrich administration". He continues to speak of reshaping Medicare in a desirable way, by referencing actions from 1996 that saved $200 billion and faced no major opposition. Another male speaker then asks about belief in "the inconvenient truth" and "global climate change advocates." Concurrently, there is constant, crackling static present in the background throughout the entire duration.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with gray hair and glasses, dressed in a dark suit and tie, is seen speaking into a microphone in a radio studio. He is identified as Newt Gingrich, a former Speaker of the House, as indicated by the text overlay on the screen. The studio is equipped with multiple computer monitors and a large screen displaying the logo "GBTV" with the tagline "the truth lives here." The atmosphere is professional, with a focus on the man's conversation, which is taking place over the phone, as suggested by the text "(on the phone)" in the overlay. The background features a model of a famous skyscraper, adding to the studio's decor. Throughout the video, the man appears engaged in the discussion, occasionally looking to his side, possibly addressing someone off-camera or reacting to the conversation. The setting remains consistent, emphasizing the formal and informative nature of the broadcast.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker dismissing "Al Gore's fantasies." He describes testifying against cap and trade after Gore spoke in favor of it before the Energy and Commerce Committee. He continues, mentioning working through American solutions to defeat the cap and trade bill in the Senate. The speaker is articulate and assertive.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with gray hair and glasses, dressed in a dark suit, is seated in a radio studio, speaking into a microphone. He is identified as Newt Gingrich, a former Speaker of the House, as indicated by the text overlay at the bottom of the screen. The studio is equipped with multiple computer monitors and a large screen displaying the logo "GBTV" with the tagline "the truth lives here." The atmosphere is professional, with a focus on the man's conversation, which is being conducted over the phone, as suggested by the text "(on the phone)" next to his name. The background features a model of a famous skyscraper, adding to the studio's decor. Throughout the video, the man appears engaged in his discussion, occasionally gesturing with his hands, while the on-screen text and studio setup remain consistent, emphasizing the continuity of the broadcast.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker describing cap and trade as an effort "by the left" to "get total control over the American economy," portraying it as centralized within a Washington bureaucracy. He speaks with conviction, suggesting the effort had "nothing to do with the environment" and everything to do with controlling lives.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man, identified as Newt Gingrich, Former Speaker of the House, engaged in a phone conversation in a professional studio setting. He is dressed in a dark suit and tie, with glasses, and is seated at a desk cluttered with papers and a microphone. The background includes a large screen displaying the logo "GBTV" with the tagline "the truth lives here," and a model of the Empire State Building, suggesting a New York City theme. Throughout the video, Gingrich appears focused and attentive, occasionally gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The on-screen text consistently identifies him and indicates that he is on the phone, with the "GBTV" logo visible in the lower right corner. The atmosphere is formal and serious, typical of a news or talk show environment.
events_list.audio_caption: Two male voices engage in conversation. The first expresses gratitude, acknowledging the potentially challenging interview, but commending the guest's willingness to answer tough questions. The second voice reciprocates, praising the interviewer's courage and truth-telling, while highlighting the positive impact on people around the country, sparking interest in American history and the founding fathers.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man dressed in a suit and tie is seen sitting at a desk in a radio studio, speaking into a microphone. He is identified as Newt Gingrich, a former Speaker of the House, as indicated by the text overlay on the screen. The studio is equipped with multiple computer monitors and a large screen displaying the logo of GBTV, which stands for "The truth lives here." The man appears to be engaged in a phone conversation, as suggested by the text "(on the phone)" displayed on the screen. The atmosphere of the studio is professional, with a focus on broadcasting and communication. The man's facial expressions and gestures suggest that he is actively participating in the conversation, possibly discussing a topic of interest or importance. The overall setting conveys a sense of authority and expertise, with the man's attire and the studio's design reinforcing this impression.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker praising someone's work, stating, "I think much of what you've done... I think you've been a very powerful force for good." He then expresses well wishes for their new venture. Another male speaker responds with a "Thank you very much." A third male voice then identifies the first speaker by name, "Newt Gingrich," and thanks him for being on the program.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a white background featuring the logo "GBTV" in black and red, accompanied by the slogan "The truth lives here." The logo is prominently displayed, with the red elements resembling signal waves emanating from the left side of the letters. The scene then transitions to a promotional message encouraging viewers to "Start your 14 Day Free Trial today!" with the website "GBTV.com" highlighted in red. The background remains white, maintaining a clean and straightforward design. The video concludes with the same promotional message, emphasizing the call to action for viewers to visit the website and begin their free trial. The overall atmosphere is professional and focused on delivering a clear message about the GBTV brand and its offerings.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with music in a hip-hop style, creating a cool and somewhat mellow atmosphere. Notable instruments include synthesized sounds and a prominent bass. This transitions to a male speaker stating "DBTV, the truth lives here" with an authoritative and declarative tone. The music then fades out as the speaker finishes.
